item.title: Australia Says US Not Making Demands Over Chinese-Owned Port
item.description: Australia’s deputy prime minister said the national government has consistently opposed Chinese ownership of the Port of Darwin and isn’t under added pressure from the Trump administration to find a new buyer for the facility that is under increased scrutiny in Canberra.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Haslinda Amin, Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Richard Marles at the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue on May 31.

item.title: Europe Sees China-Russia Threat as World’s ‘Greatest Challenge’
item.description: European leaders headed to Asia this week with a key message: We need to work closer together to preserve the rules-based order against threats from China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Kaja Kallas, vice president of the European Commission, during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, May 31. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Hegseth Warns Allies About China, Presses Defense Spending
item.description: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth pressed US partners in Asia to boost defense spending toward 5% of gross domestic product, warning that more urgency is needed to prepare for a potential Chinese invasion of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride, Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: A member of the Taiwan military monitors Chinese drills near the island in this photo supplied by Taiwan’s Military News Agency of the Ministry of National Defense, in 2024.

item.title: Trump Says Chinese Students at US Colleges Will Be ‘Fine’
item.description: President Donald Trump sought to downplay worries among Chinese student visa holders over his administration’s scrutiny, saying he would tell them that everything would be “fine” as they pursue their studies in the US.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: This photo taken on July 24, 2020 shows student Lin Xiaobin reading a book at her home in Beijing. - Faced with hostility from US President Donald Trump, discrimination and a surging pandemic, Chinese students are postponing their long-held plans to study in the United States. (Photo by WANG ZHAO / AFP) / TO GO WITH China-education-diplomacy-US-student,FOCUS by Lillian Ding and Ludovic Ehret (Photo by WANG ZHAO/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: WANG ZHAO/AFP

item.title: Trump to Hike Steel, Aluminum Tariffs to Aid Nippon-US Steel
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel and aluminum to 50% from 25%, saying the move would help protect American workers, as he visited a United States Steel Corp. plant on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump arrives at the US Steel Corporation Irvin Works facility in West Mifflin, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The US government could receive a so-called golden share - or powers akin to it - in United States Steel Corp. as a condition for approving a $14 billion takeover by Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp.

item.title: Musk Pledges to Remain Trump Adviser After Washington Exit
item.description: Elon Musk said he would continue to advise President Donald Trump even after stepping away from the Department of Government Efficiency effort he has spearheaded.
item.dc:creator: Dana Hull, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Tesla CEO Elon Musk and US President Donald Trump during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 30.

item.title: Malaysian Minister’s Party Switch Bid to Test Ruling Coalition
item.description: Malaysia’s Trade Minister Zafrul Aziz said he is switching political parties, in a move set to test the relationship between two of the partners in the nation’s ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Zafrul Aziz

item.title: Shangri-La Dialogue Defense Summit

media:content.media:description: A worker walks inside a hall at the venue of 22nd Shangri-La Dialogue summit in Singapore, Thursday, May 29, 2025. (AP Photo/Anupam Nath)

item.title: K-Pop and Breakdance Power South Korea’s High-Stakes Presidential Race
item.description: In South Korea’s high-stakes presidential campaign, K-pop isn’t just a cultural backdrop — it’s a political strategy.
item.dc:creator: Sohee Kim

media:content.media:description: Dancers perform ahead of Lee Jae-myung's campaign event in Incheon on May 21. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Rubio Says Lack of Social-Media Profile Could Prompt Visa Denial
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Friday ordered more scrutiny of the social-media profiles of any foreigners seeking to visit Harvard University, telling US consular officers that applicants’ lack of an online presence might be enough evidence to deny a visa.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Banners hang from Memorial Church on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: Trump Clings to Good News While Risks Pile Up Fast
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Friday, White House correspondent Akayla Gardner delivers a roundup of the key news and events in politics, policy and economics that you need to know. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

item.title: Trump Sees Xi Call Settling Trade Flap Over Rare Earth Exports
item.description: US President Donald Trump expressed confidence a talk with Chinese President Xi Jinping could ease fresh trade tensions, after White House officials vented anger over Beijing’s pace of issuing promised export licenses.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: A container ship approaches the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: Russia to Attend New Talks as Ukraine Demands Peace Outline
item.description: Russia said it’s sending a delegation to Istanbul on Monday for a second round of talks with Ukraine amid wrangling over Kyiv’s insistence that Moscow outline its peace proposals before any meeting.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: The site of a Russian missile attack in Kyiv, on May 25.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Court Fights to Outlast His Time in the White House
item.description: As Elon Musk leaves his formal US government position, dozens of legal challenges over the billionaire’s powerful role in the Trump administration and the work of the Department of Government Efficiency will press ahead.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Trump Memecoins Complicate Legislative Effort, GOP Lawmaker Says
item.description: House Financial Services Chairman French Hill said activity by President Donald Trump in cryptocurrency and memecoins has complicated work in Congress to pass legislation that’s been in the works for years.
item.dc:creator: Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: French Hill

item.title: Northern US Mayors Call for End to ‘Irrational’ Trade War With Canada
item.description: Mayors in states that border Canada are calling for an end to President Donald Trump’s trade war with the country, saying it has harmed businesses and workers in their communities and upended one of the world’s most successful economic relationships.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: A tractor-trailer traveling into the United States at the Canada-US border in St-Bernard-de-Lacolle, Quebec.

item.title: Trump Rails Against Tariff Judges, Conservative Legal Group
item.description: After a day of legal wrangling over his tariffs, President Donald Trump took to social media to attack the judges who ruled against him as well as a more surprising target: a powerful conservative legal group that helped shape his first-term judicial picks.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 25, 2025. The Trump administration is putting pressure on Europe to ditch a rulebook that would compel developers of advanced artificial intelligence to follow stricter standards of transparency, risk-mitigation and copyright rules.

item.title: Zelenskiy Plans to Discuss ‘Possible’ Monday Talks With Erdogan
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy plans to speak to Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday, according to his daily video address.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, during a news conference with Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. Zelenskiy called on western allies to provide about $30 billion by the end of the year to boost domestic weapons production and hold off Russia’s advance.

item.title: Trump Says Macron ‘Fine’ After Viral Shoving Incident With Wife
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he spoke to Emmanuel Macron after a viral video showed the French president being shoved in the face by his wife.
item.dc:creator: Justin Sink

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Trump to Strip 500,000 of Legal Status
item.description: The Supreme Court let President Donald Trump’s administration immediately strip the legal right to temporarily live and work in the US from as many as half a million people from Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump ‘Revenge’ Tax Would Cut Foreign Investment, Congressional Panel Says
item.description: Congress’s own official tax scorekeeper is predicting a “revenge” tax buried in Donald Trump’s massive fiscal package would realize Wall Street’s fears and drive foreign investors away from US markets.
item.dc:creator: Michael Rapoport, Liz Capo McCormick, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans.

item.title: Democrats Slam Hegseth’s Plan to Cut Weapons-Testing Office
item.description: The top Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee slammed Pentagon plans to slash staffing at the office that oversees tests of major weapons systems, after Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth claimed the cuts would save the government $300 million.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth

item.title: Courthouse Arrests Stun Migrants Who Showed Up for Their Hearing
item.description: In courts across the US, migrants who arrive expecting a routine hearing are instead seeing judges dismiss their case and government agents waiting to arrest them.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: Federal agents take a person into custody outside an immigration court in Phoenix on May 21.

item.title: Farmers Press Trump on Biofuels to Counter Tariffs Hit
item.description: After losing their biggest export market due to Donald Trump’s trade wars, US farmers are now counting on the president’s support for biofuels to prevent their next crop from piling up in storage.
item.dc:creator: Kim Chipman, Alicia Diaz, Erin Ailworth, Ilena Peng

media:content.media:description: A combine harvester cuts, threshes, and cleans soybeans during a harvest in Waynesfield, Ohio. Photographer: Matthew Hatcher/Bloomberg

item.title: Tariff Revenues Rise Sharply in Canada After Retaliation Against Trump Levies
item.description: A spike in custom import duties shows proceeds from retaliatory tariffs are starting to roll into the coffers of Canada’s federal government.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Trucks at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario.

item.title: US Transport Department Pauses Planned Workforce Cuts Due to Litigation
item.description: The US Transportation Department said it’s pausing planned cuts to its workforce while it waits for resolution in pending legal battles over the Trump administration’s efforts to significantly reduce the size of the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille

media:content.media:description: The Department of Transportation headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Graham Expects Russia Sanctions Bill to ‘Start Moving’ Next Week
item.description: South Carolina Republican Lindsey Graham said the Senate is likely to “start moving” on new punishing sanctions against Russia next week because of the lack of progress toward a ceasefire in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, center, speaks during a confirmation hearing for Russell Vought, director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) nominee for US President Donald Trump, in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025. The Senate Budget Committee will have to approve Vought's nomination before he receives a full Senate confirmation vote, after the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee voted 8-7 to advance Vought's nomination on Monday.

item.title: Israel Accepts New US Gaza Truce Plan as Hamas Remains Wary
item.description: Israel accepted a US ceasefire proposal for Gaza that Israeli officials familiar with the matter said would involve a 60-day pause in fighting and restore United Nations-led aid distribution to the Palestinian territory.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams, Fadwa Hodali

media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry boxes of humanitarian aid collected from a distribution center in the Netzarim Corridor, central Gaza Strip, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The US and Israel-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation says it opened a fourth distribution site and three of its four sites were fully operational and dispensed aid on Thursday.

item.title: US Plans Wider China Tech Sanctions With Subsidiary Crackdown
item.description: The Trump administration plans to broaden restrictions on China’s tech sector with new regulations to capture subsidiaries of companies under US curbs.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: A wafer on display at the Semicon China expo in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The expo runs through March 22.

item.title: Key Republican Hopes ‘Revenge’ Tax Will Be a Never-Used Deterrent
item.description: A key House Republican tax negotiator said he hopes the so-called “revenge” measure in President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill targeting foreign investors will be a deterrent that is never deployed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: The rotunda at the US Capitol in Washington DC, US, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The White House amped up the pressure on Republicans on Wednesday urging lawmakers to quickly approve President Donald Trump’s signature tax bill, adding that a failure to do so would be the “ultimate betrayal.”
